discussion.content:
B - Network-based
The application installation method that requires the use of a valid IP address is the network-based installation method. When installing an application over a network, the system needs to communicate with a specific IP address to download and install the software. This method is commonly used for remote installations or when deploying software across multiple devices within a network. Other installation methods, such as USB, script-based, or CD-ROM installations, do not necessarily rely on IP addresses for their execution.
aka PXE

questions.question_text: Which of the following application installation methods requires the use of a valid IP address?

discussion.content: It's definitely B.

B-Rebuild the user profile

The technician should rebuild the user profile. If the missing files cannot be found in the recycle bin, itâ€™s possible that the userâ€™s profile has become corrupted, and they are logging in as a temporary user. Rebuilding the profile will likely fix the issue. This step is a sensible next move before considering more drastic actions like reinstalling the operating system or disabling update services. 

By rebuilding the user profile, the technician can address any profile-related issues that might be causing the missing files.
Remember, starting with the least intrusive solution is often the best approach to troubleshooting technical problems. ðŸ˜Š

Selected Answer: B
Voting B since likely the user's profile has become corrupted and they are logging in as a temporary user. Rebuilding the profile will likely fix the issue.

Selected Answer: B
It has to be B. The question doesn't even mention a recent update, so why would we assume that caused the problem? The other two options are too radical to start with, so that leaves B as the only option.
Per Professor Messer the answer would be B

questions.question_text: A customer is missing files from the Desktop and Documents folders after logging on to a PC. A technician looks in the Recycle Bin for the items, but nothing is there. Which of the following steps should the technician take NEXT?

A technician has been asked to review the configuration of an executive's SOHO network following a recent news report regarding home Internet routers that are being added to botnets for malicious purposes. Which of the following would be BEST to prevent the router from being added to a botnet? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
To prevent a router from being added to a botnet and enhance its security, consider the following measures:

1. Change Default Credentials:
Many routers come with default usernames and passwords, which are often well-known and easily exploited by attackers. Change the default credentials to unique, strong ones to prevent unauthorised access.

2. Update Router Firmware:
Regularly update your routerâ€™s firmware to patch security vulnerabilities. Newer firmware versions often include security enhancements and bug fixes.
However, keep in mind that some older routers may not receive updates, so consider upgrading to a more recent model if necessary.

comments.content:
Remember that securing your router is crucial for protecting your entire network. Implementing these steps will help reduce the risk of your router being compromised by a botnet or other malicious actors. Additionally, consider other practices such as disabling unused ports, monitoring network traffic for anomalies, and using antivirus software to further enhance security.

C & D is correct.

discussion.content:
https://www.professormesser.com/free-a-plus-training/220-1002/securing-a-soho-network-2/

Professor Messer discussed about SOHO wireless network to upgrade firmware and change default creds
I understand C but why D? My other choice would have been B

comments.content: I think because it's a SOHO network, there shouldn't be any need to use Enterprise-level gear. It's all about securing a simple home-use router. Updating firmware would prevent botnets from exploiting vulnerabilities in previous firmware versions. That's my thinking anyway...

choices.F: Disabling the SSID from being broadcast

A technician remotes in and determines Internet pages load slowly or not at all, CPU performance is normal, and the local router can successfully ping. The remote connection drops periodically.
Which of the following steps should the technician take NEXT to resolve the problem?

Once again, this makes no sense to me. If internet access is extremely slow or non-existent, how does the tech expect to be able to *download* the latest anti-virus updates? As I stated in question 36, if these are the types of questions that will be asked on a REAL exam, then I am SCREWED...

discussion.content: OBJ-3.2: Based on the symptoms, it appears that the system may be infected with malware. Therefore, it would be best to attempt to remediate the system by updating the anti-virus, performing a full system scan, and then verifying that the web browser and email client's settings are correct.

How to remove malware from a PC
*******************************
Step 1: Disconnect from the internet. ...
Step 2: Enter safe mode. ...
Step 3: Check your activity monitor for malicious applications. ...
Step 4: Run a malware scanner. ...
Step 5: Fix your web browser. ...
Step 6: Clear your cache.

comments.content: If a virus is suspected, it is actually best to disconnect asap, to prevent it from spreading.
Before you disconnect, you should check, whether there is a virus

discussion.content:
It doesn't specifically say to download the definitions on that machine. In the steps for malware removal you are recommended to download the definitions on a clean machine then transfer via usb and install manually.
The question asks what you would try NEXT, C and D don't make any sense. A could fix it as it could be an update problem but is a more intrusive fix.
B can be attempted relitively quickly by checking a few settings and running an anti virus scan. If that didn't turn up anything then the next step would probably be A.
process of elimination.. B

comments.content: Rethink this. ID the problem - done. Establish & test a theory of probable cause - very likely malware at this point. Establish an action plan to remove malware. At this point use your IQ DR. SEE acronym to remove malware. I - ID & research (already done) Q - Quarantine the infected systems - done or do it. D - disable system restore (do it & non-player in question) and then R - Remediate the infected system through updating the antimalware software, scan & use removal techniques in safe mode etc. BEST answer is B within the context of the troubleshooting theory, malware removal and context of the question.

The steps to troubleshoot malware are different.... these are the general steps from 1001...

Comptia malware removal steps
Be sure to follow these steps in order.
Identify and research malware symptoms. ...
Quarantine the infected systems. ...
Disable System Restore (in Windows). ...
Remediate the infected systems. ...
Schedule scans and run updates. ...
Enable System Restore and create a restore point (in Windows). ...
Educate the end user.
Based on Json Dion's Tips from Udemy, when there is no single answer that makes sense you will need to just pick the one that makes more sense than the rest of the options.

discussion.content:
None are correct - they do not comply with the six steps of troubleshooting.
1. Identify the problem. ...
2. Establish a theory of probable cause. ...
3. Test probable cause theory to determine actual cause. ...
4. Establish an action plan and execute the plan. ...
5. Verify full system functionality. ...
6. Document the process.
Step 1 - completed - problem identified 
Step 2 - incomplete - no theory of probable cause yet - tech jumps to step 4

choices.A: Reboot into safe mode, uninstall the latest OS update, and run a repair on the OS
choices.D: Send a test email, open a command prompt to check the file system, and empty the browser cache
choices.B: Update the antivirus software, run an antivirus scan, verify the browser settings, and check all email settings
choices.C: Reboot to BIOS setup, verify the TPM is enabled, and start a System Restore from safe mode

The DiskPart command that can be used to restore the drive, allowing it to be formatted to full capacity is:
C. clean
This command will remove all partitions from the drive, effectively restoring it to its original state and allowing you to format it to its full capacity

Selected Answer: C

volume information off the currently selected disk. This tool handles nasty
corruptions that simply wonâ€™t let Windows boot and serves as my last-ditch
step before I toss a drive."
